image.altText: Black and white image of Whetoi Pomare

props.synopsis: Aotearoa New Zealand has had a treaty in place for almost two centuries but it wasn't until the 1970s that it was truly honoured. So what happened and what are the lessons for Australia ahead of the Voice referendum?

image.altText: Hospital staff in scrubs run.

image.altText: Andrews, Albanese and Palaszczuk sit at a long table with some papers talking, with others out of frame.

image.altText: hands hold an orange alarm clock against a blue background

props.synopsis: Here's your quick pocket guide on daylight saving as Australia comes into the warmer months.

image.altText: Sheep looking at camera in sale yard pen.

title.children: Farmers say live export ban will jeopardise trade relationship as prices continue to fall

image.altText: Two people stand in front of a large submarine with Taiwanese flag symbol draped over it.

image.altText: Michael Gambon as Dumbeldore in Harry Potter

props.synopsis: Michael Gambon, who played Dumbledore in Harry Potter, has died peacefully in hospital, according to a family statement.

title.children: Harry Potter actor Sir Michael Gambon dies aged 82

image.altText: Tiwi Bombers footy players line up with linked arms

props.synopsis: Multiple suicides have left communities mourning in the Top End of the Northern Territory, as new data shows an alarming increase in the jurisdiction's suicide rate.

title.children: Prominent Tiwi footballer among series of suicides in remote NT, as data shows territory rate climbing

image.altText: Wesley Enoch, sitting on a rock in a park on a sunny day, looks at the camera with his hands clasped.

props.synopsis: The lead-up to the Voice referendum has taken a toll on the mental health of many people, especially in First Nations communities. Psychologists share their tips on how to manage stress and anxiety during a challenging time.

title.children: 'I feel like I'm not in charge': What to do if the Voice debate is taking a toll on your mental health

image.altText: A composite picture of two men, one with a blue shirt on the left and one beside a tree on the right.

props.synopsis: The former chair of ATSIC and the former head of Victoria's Aboriginal community at Framlingham share a bloodline and a community, but they remain firmly divided on the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: This Indigenous community has long been divided and the Voice is widening the rift

image.altText: A painted image of a white car, with an electrical cord attached, on a green background.

props.synopsis: Australia's electric vehicle market is set to expand rapidly in the coming years, but experts fear that access to power for their EVs won't be simple for everyone.

title.children: So you want an electric car, but will you be able to charge it?

image.altText: A road sign on the side of a country highway indicating the way to Cloncurry and Julia Creek.

props.synopsis: Two survivors are in hospital and police are searching the area for a fifth person who may have been in the vehicle.

title.children: Two dead after crash in outback Queensland, police search for possible missing passenger

image.altText: Jacinta Allan wears a white jacket and glasses and smiles while Ben Carroll stands behind her with a tight lipped smile.

props.synopsis: It should have been a smooth transition of power from the then-premier to his deputy, but it was very far from it in the fiery meeting that forced Ben Carroll to back down.

title.children: Messy, tense and heated: What unfolded inside caucus as Jacinta Allan became Victoria's new premier

image.altText: Several countries, an ocean and a large amount of cloud, seen from space.

props.synopsis: A hybrid weather system, this "Mediterranean hurricane" is already responsible for more than 11,000 deaths and massive damage bills — this is how it forms and why we could see them intensify in future.

title.children: The world’s deadliest storm to strike this year was a monster — and the 'medicane' could be getting worse

image.altText: Next to just visible blue pool water, a woman with sunglasses and stripy top lays with phone held over her face.

props.synopsis: If you're trying to change bad habits at work or home, this expert says ignore the traditional approaches to changing behaviour.

title.children: This behavioural scientist says the key to better habits is more celebrations and less abstractions

image.altText: Trump grimaces as he speaks at a rally outside in the hot sun, with sweat visible on his face.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Court rejects Donald Trump's bid to delay trial in wake of fraud ruling. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will no longer be used by the defence force. Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July. The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing. In a statement, Defence Minister Richard Marles has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024. You can continue reading this story by political reporter Georgia Roberts below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

featuredLink.title: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

props.alt: Taipan helicopter kicks up dust as it takes off.

children.content: (Supplied: Department of Defence)
The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will
no longer be used by the defence force.
Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July
The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing.
In a statement, Defence Minister
Richard Marles
has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024.
You can continue reading this story by political reporter
Georgia Roberts
below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, this morning the final report from the disability royal commission will be released. The Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability is four-and-a-half years in the making. Senator Jordon Steele-John was on News Breakfast moments ago and reflected on the importance of the release of the report. "I think it is really important that we pay tribute to the determination, to the dedication, to the fierce advocacy of the disability community, of disabled people who have experienced violence, abuse and neglect and exploitation, who nevertheless have worked together, campaigned together, to establish this royal commission," he said. "Today is a day where we collectively, as a community, are this morning holding our breath, with a fair amount of anxiety about what the contents of the report will be. "But also a determination that we will see an end to segregation in Australia, that we will see an end to the abuse that we have been subjected to as a community, and that we will see the urgent change that is needed to end violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation wherever it exists in society."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Jordon Steele-John says disability community has 'a fair amount of anxiety' about potential contents of report

children.content: As I mentioned earlier, this morning the final report from the disability royal commission will be released.
The Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability is four-and-a-half years in the making.
Senator
Jordon Steele-John
was on News Breakfast moments ago and reflected on the importance of the release of the report.

props.alt: Jordan sits and speaks from his home.

children.content: Jordon Steele-John.
(News Breakfast)
"I think it is really important that
we pay tribute to the determination, to the dedication, to the fierce advocacy of the disability community
, of disabled people who have experienced violence, abuse and neglect and exploitation, who nevertheless have worked together, campaigned together, to establish this royal commission," he said.
"Today is a day where we collectively, as a community, are this morning holding our breath, with a
fair amount of anxiety about what the contents of the report will be.
"But
also a determination that we will see an end to segregation in Australia

, that we will see an end to the abuse that we have been subjected to as a community, and that we will see the urgent change that is needed to end violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation wherever it exists in society."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Donald Trump will not seek to move a criminal case alleging he conspired to reverse his 2020 presidential election loss in Georgia from state to federal court, his lawyers have said. The development could simplify the former US president's path to trial. Trump, the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and 18 others are charged with pressuring Georgia election officials to overturn his loss in the state to Democratic President Joe Biden in 2020. Trump and his co-defendants have denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Breaking: Trump will not seek to move his Georgia case to federal court

children.content: Donald Trump
will not seek to move a criminal case alleging he conspired to reverse his 2020 presidential election loss in
Georgia
from state to federal court, his lawyers have said.
The development could simplify the former US president's path to trial.
Trump, the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, and 18 others are
charged with pressuring Georgia election officials
to overturn his loss in the state to Democratic President Joe Biden in 2020.
Trump and his co-defendants have
denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty.

props.alt: A composite of several mug shots, including Donald Trump.

children.content: This is the fourth criminal indictment against Trump and the source of the infamous mug shot.
(Fulton County Jail)

image.altText: Bridget McKenzie, wearing a dark suit, sits behind a desk and looks at a woman wearing a lilac jacket sitting across from her.
